baseline_groups.claim_summary: House prices respond positively to city-specific income shocks: a 1% increase in lagged income (L1) raises house prices by 0.29%, estimated from the price equation of a 5-variable Panel VAR(2) with city and time FE on 106 US MSAs (1982-2007).
baseline_groups.notes: Coefficient 0.2909 (SE 0.0398, t=7.32, p<0.0001). N=2544, R2=0.943. This is the paper's key empirical result, matching the reported estimate (0.2909403) exactly. The price equation captures how income shocks propagate to house prices in the structural Panel VAR used to calibrate the search-theoretic model.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Wages exhibit strong persistence: the L1 income coefficient in the wage equation is 1.11, reflecting the high autocorrelation of the income process that drives house price dynamics.
baseline_groups.notes: Coefficient 1.1081 (SE 0.0209, t=53.01, p<0.0001). N=2544, R2=0.832. Wage equation of the baseline VAR(2). The near-unit-root income process is a key input to the structural model calibration.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Sales growth responds positively to income shocks: L1 income increases sales growth by 0.39pp, consistent with search friction dynamics where income shocks stimulate housing market activity.
baseline_groups.notes: Coefficient 0.3870 (SE 0.1281, t=3.02, p=0.003). N=2544, R2=0.179. Sales growth equation of the baseline VAR(2).

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Construction rates respond positively to income shocks: L1 income raises the construction rate by 0.037pp, reflecting the housing supply response to demand shocks.
baseline_groups.notes: Coefficient 0.0365 (SE 0.0048, t=7.65, p<0.0001). N=2544, R2=0.653. Construction rate equation of the baseline VAR(2).

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Population growth responds positively to income shocks: L1 income increases population growth by 0.074pp, capturing migration responses to local income changes.
baseline_groups.notes: Coefficient 0.0736 (SE 0.0224, t=3.29, p=0.001). N=2544, R2=0.688. Population growth equation of the baseline VAR(2).

global_notes: Paper is 'Search, Liquidity, and the Dynamics of House Prices and Construction' by Head, Lloyd-Ellis, and Sun (AER 2014). The main empirical contribution is a structural Panel VAR(2) with 5 endogenous variables (income, price, sales growth, construction rate, population growth) estimated via equation-by-equation LSDV on 106 US MSAs, 1982-2007. The primary result of interest (G1) is the income-to-price coefficient, which calibrates the structural search model. The other 4 equations (G2-G5) are also baseline components of the full VAR system. The specification search reports 65 total specifications. Most robustness checks focus on the price equation (G1) income coefficient. The spec search confirms the main result (L1_wx = 0.2909) is replicable and matches the paper's reported estimates. The VAR(1) specification produces a near-zero, insignificant price-income coefficient (0.0005), suggesting the lag structure matters. The result is sensitive to time period (early-only gives 0.065, insignificant), outlier treatment (winsorize/trim at 5% reduces to 0.04-0.13), and geographic subsample (coastal cities: 0.11 vs non-coastal: 0.38). Five L2 income coefficient specs and four price-effect-on-other-variables specs extract different parameters from the same baseline VAR system and are classified as non-core.
